subject: AI
title: State Management
description: Tracking what the agent knows and where it is in a task.

hook.text: Your agent is halfway through a 10-step task. The API call fails. When you restart the agent, it starts from step 1. All progress lost.

buildup.text: State management persists the agent's progress: which steps are complete, what data has been collected, what the current plan is. Think of it as a save file for the agent.

discovery.text: LangGraph models state as a graph: nodes are steps, edges are transitions, and the current state is a checkpoint. If the agent crashes, resume from the last checkpoint.

twist.text: State adds complexity: now you need to serialize intermediate results, handle partial failures, and manage state cleanup. For simple agents, a message history is sufficient state.

climax.text: Use explicit state management for multi-step tasks that take more than a few seconds. For quick single-turn tool calls, the message history is your state.

punchline.text: Can your agent survive a crash and pick up where it left off? That's the state management test.

quiz.question: Why is state management important for agents?
options: It allows resuming from where the agent left off after failures
It reduces the number of API calls
State management is only for databases
